The Internet makes it possible to saunter through a virtual auto showroom. But one thing has been missing: a sales pitch. That is about to change.

THE Internet makes it possible to do a lot of things at 3 o'clock on a Sunday morning, including sauntering through an auto showroom -- a virtual one, that is. But one thing has been missing: a sales pitch.

A year after introducing Motormouth, a series of CDs for car salespeople to play during test drives, Steve Levin is introducing a line of nerve-soothing studio-produced pitches to accompany photos on the Web sites of automakers and dealers. A sample of the online product can be heard by clicking on the dealer sample page at motormouthaudio.com.
Mr. Levin and his staff plan to produce 4,500 four-to-six-minute tracks -- one for almost every car made by major manufacturers. The pitches should appear online in May.
Mr. Levin, a former car dealer who lives in Eatontown, N.J., will be distributing the audio files through Autodata, a provider of research.

According to Mr. Levin, 70 to 80 percent of customers research automobiles on the Internet before buying. Most times, people make their choice based on price, not because they fill a particular need. ''In my 32 years in this business, I've found a lot of times people spend a lot of money to buy a new car, and when they go home it doesn't measure up to what they thought,'' Mr. Levin said.
While developing the Motormouth CDs, Mr. Levin's wife, Carol, suggested that the studio-produced pitches could be put on dealers' and manufacturers' sites, enhancing their appeal.
Mr. Levin knows buying a car can be stressful. A dealer might forget something during a pitch, and a buyer might forget to ask a question.

There are no audio files for online haggling with a virtual sales clerk -- yet. But he believes the product will help dealers make buyers more aware of a vehicle's features, and it will help buyers feel they have made a better decision before a big purchase.
''This is a win-win for everybody,'' Mr. Levin said.
